Description:
Experience the creative genius of the nation’s most gifted authors, past and present.

We will read Sarah Orne Jewett’s The Country of the Pointed Firs, Dave Eggers' A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, Alice McDermott’s Charming Billy, Sinclair Lewis’s Babbitt and James Salter’s Dusk and Other Stories.

 

Class Meets: Mon, Feb 9, Mar 9, Apr 13, May 11 and Jun 1.
ShortDesc: Experience the creative genius of the nation’s most gifted authors, past and present.
Title: Great American Fiction

Description:
Enjoy the stunning work of these authors from around the world.

We will read Joseph O’Neill’s Netherland, Javier Marias’ A Heart So White, Margaret Atwood’s Oryx and Crake, J. M. Coetzee’s Disgrace and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala’s Heat and Dust.

 

Class Meets: Tue, Feb 10, Mar 10, Apr 14, May 12 and Jun 2.
ShortDesc: Enjoy the stunning work of these authors from around the world.
Title: Best of World Literature

Description:
The operative word here is “arguably.”

Read the books, discuss their meanings and messages, and, of course, argue their merits (or demerits). Books include Housekeeping by Marilynne Robinson, The Good Soldier by Ford Madox Ford, The Member of the Wedding by Carson McCullers, The Trial by Franz Kafka and Winesburg, Ohio by Sherwood Anderson.

Please read Housekeeping for the first class.

 

Class Meets: Tue, Feb 3, Mar 10 & 31, Apr 28 and Jun 2.
ShortDesc: The operative word here is “arguably.”
Title: Arguably, Some of the Best Books of the 20th Century

Description:
We’ll first pick up the trail of Dorothy Sayers’ elegant detective, Lord Peter Wimsey, as he tries to discover Whose Body? was found in a bathtub.

Clouds of Witness will next puzzle us, and then we’ll investigate Unnatural Death and The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club, winding up with a dose of Strong Poison.

Please read Whose Body? for the first session.
ShortDesc: We’ll first pick up the trail of Dorothy Sayers’ elegant detective, Lord Peter Wimsey, as he tries to discover Whose Body? was found in a bathtub.
Title: Dorothy Sayers’ Suave Sleuth

Description:
We’re back on the case with Dorothy Sayers’ debonair detective, Lord Peter Wimsey, as he investigates Five Red Herrings, romances Harriet Vane in Have His Carcase, learns that Murder Must Advertise, rings the bell with The Nine Tailors and finds true love during Gaudy Night.

Please read Five Red Herrings for the first session.
ShortDesc: We’re back on the case with Dorothy Sayers’ debonair detective, Lord Peter Wimsey, as he investigates Five Red Herrings, romances Harriet Vane in Have His Carcase, learns that Murder Must Advertise, rings the bell with The Nine Tailors and finds true love during Gaudy Night.
Title: Dorothy Sayers’ Dashing Detective

Description:
The Reformation profoundly challenged traditional religious beliefs, and New World voyages and Eastern trade ventures exposed the English to varied and alien faiths.

This course will consider a selection of Shakespeare plays that reflect these dramatic developments, beginning with The Merchant of Venice and Hamlet.

 

Brief Bio

Richard McCoy is distinguished professor of English at Queens College and The Graduate Center, CUNY, and the author of Faith in Shakespeare (Oxford, 2013).
ShortDesc: The Reformation profoundly challenged traditional religious beliefs, and New World voyages and Eastern trade ventures exposed the English to varied and alien faiths.
Title: Coffee & Classics: Shakespeare and Religion

Description:
This seminar proposes to examine the phenomenon of Confessional poetry.

What did these four poets write about themselves that merits the rubric “Confessional?” Each poet lived in turmoil. Three of the four poets committed suicide. How did they lay bare their psyches in their poems? How do we as readers feel about listening to a recital of so much personal unhappiness? How do their conflicted lives get expressed in the styles and forms of their poems? Sexton and Plath were students of Lowell at Boston University and Berryman was a good friend of his. Do they comprise a school of poetry? And one last important question: the traditional lyric poem is a kind of self-communion and sometimes exposes raw nerves and psychological crises. How do the lyric poems of this quartet differ from a Shakespeare sonnet, one of Coleridge’s romantic meditation, “Frost at Midnight,” or Modernist poems saturated in angst? This class will attempt to answer the above questions. This class will focus on Lowell’s Life Studies, Berryman’s Dream Songs, Plath’s Ariel and a selection of Anne Sexton’s poems.

 

Brief Bio

Herbert Leibowitz is the founder and editor of Parnassus: Poetry in Review and the author of "Something Urgent I Have to Say To You": The Life and Works of William Carlos Williams.
ShortDesc: This seminar proposes to examine the phenomenon of Confessional poetry.
Title: Reading Berryman, Lowell, Plath and Sexton with Herbert Leibowitz

Description:
The aging Lear fantasizes a semiretirement, letting his three daughters take over.

He sets a trap: Who shows most love earns the biggest slice. Slather me in sycophantic verbiage. The first two girls do a terrific job, but the youngest decides to tell her father the truth. All hell breaks loose. The old king ends up abandoned in a storm worthy of the damned on the back wall of the Sistine Chapel. And this is only part one!

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: The aging Lear fantasizes a semiretirement, letting his three daughters take over.
Title: King Lear

Description:
“I sound my barbaric yawp over the rooftops of the world,” Walt Whitman announced in Leaves of Grass.

We'll commemorate the volume's 160th anniversary by closely reading it alongside much of his work, paying attention to his ability to “contain multitudes,” (both in life and language), his virtuosity, his generosity and his singular but dramatic influence on American letters.

 

Brief Bio

Brenda Wineapple is the award-winning author of White Heat, a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle award and Ecstatic Nation, a "beautifully written, artfully constructed, and passionately argued [...] narrative history,” writes Ron Chernow. She teaches at the New School and Columbia University.
ShortDesc: “I sound my barbaric yawp over the rooftops of the world,” Walt Whitman announced in Leaves of Grass, whose 160th anniversary we’ll commemorate by closely reading that volume and much of his work.
Title: Reading Whitman with Brenda Wineapple

Description:
Read The Oresteia, Oedipus the King and The Bacchae—three of the most dramatic, illuminating and disturbing works ever created—and discuss ancient and modern psychology, literary form, and the works’ implications for personal morality, the life of the family and the state.

 

Brief Bio

Edward Mendelson is the Lionel Trilling Professor in the Humanities at Columbia University and the author of The Things That Matter: What Seven Classic Novels Have to Say about the Stages of Life and Moral Agents.
ShortDesc: Read The Oresteia, Oedipus the King and The Bacchae—three of the most dramatic, illuminating and disturbing works ever created—and discuss ancient and modern psychology, literary form, and the works’ implications for personal morality, the life of the family and the state.
Title: Greek Tragedy with Edward Mendelson

Description:
Every poem, short or long, has to turn toward its conclusion.

Some turn with advance notice; others come rushing in the last half of the last line, hair undone. We will read, then write, poems that pace their conclusions from explosion to whisper, from shock to reassurance.

Class meets: Feb 8, 22, Mar 1 and 8.

 

Brief Bio

Molly Peacock is the author of The Paper Garden, How to Read a Poem and Start a Poetry Circle and The Second Blush. One of the creators of New York’s Poetry in Motion program, she serves as the series editor of The Best Canadian Poetry in English.
ShortDesc: Every poem, short or long, has to turn toward its conclusion.
Title: The Magic of the Turn with Molly Peacock

Description:
Finnegans Wake is a hilarious and beautiful experiment.

Over four Sundays we will focus on several excerpts in an attempt to gain some understanding of Joyce’s work—and some joy in it. As the drinking song that inspired Joyce’s title puts it, there is “lots of fun at Finnegans Wake.”

“Crucial parts of my life are all intimately tied to Joyce, who writes the kind of work of art that rewards readers in different ways depending on the stage of life they are at, their backgrounds and interests, their talents as readers and their limitations – but does reward every reader who lets it do that,” writes instructor Michael Groden.

Our students say: “Dr. Groden gave us his prodigious knowledge along with such freshness and enthusiasm. He has opened a world of richness and stimulation and insight for me that has and will continue to enrich my life. The pleasures of reading Joyce seem more attainable and the challenges less difficult. I could not have wished for a better class.”

Class meets: Feb 8, 22, Mar 1 and 8.

 

Brief Bio

Scholar and critic Michael Groden is the author of Ulysses in Progress and the new Ulysses in Focus, general editor of The James Joyce Archive, a recipient of an honorary DLitt degree from University College Dublin and Distinguished University Professor of English at the University of Western Ontario.
ShortDesc: Finnegans Wake is a hilarious and beautiful experiment. Over four Sundays we will focus on several excerpts in an attempt to gain some understanding of Joyce’s work—and some joy in it.
Title: Reading Finnegans Wake with Michael Groden

Description:
Explore the surprising back-stories and timeless revelations of four of children’s literature’s best-loved tales: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, The Wind in the Willows, Peter Pan and The Secret Garden.

How did it happen that at a high moment of scientific discovery, nationalist fervor, and social transformation, a mathematician, a banker, a playwright and a romance writer all made their most enduring marks as authors of storybook fantasies for children? Who were their illustrators? Who were their critics? Why are their books still read more than a century later?

Class meets on Wednesdays: Feb 11 and 25 and Mar 11 and 25.

 

Brief Bio

Leonard S. Marcus is one of the children’s book world’s most respected writers, historians and critics. He is the author of books on Randolph Caldecott, Maurice Sendak and Madeline L’Engle, among others, as well as the curator of The ABC of It: Why Children’s Books Matter at the New York Public Library.
ShortDesc: Explore the surprising back-stories and timeless revelations of four of children’s literature’s best-loved tales: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, The Wind in the Willows, Peter Pan and The Secret Garden.
Title: Down the Rabbit Hole and Beyond: Four Children’s Classics Revisited With Leonard S. Marcus

Description:
The best of readers sometimes discover books that are either too long or too difficult to get through.

It may be because of subject matter, language, pacing, plot or vocabulary. Don’t be discouraged; you’re not alone. Join us to read and analyze just such a book: Middlemarch, by George Eliot.
ShortDesc: The best of readers sometimes discover books that are either too long or too difficult to get through.
Title: Middlemarch by George Eliot

Description:
Join professional artists from the Massachusetts-based Elements Theatre Company to unlock the secrets of Shakespeare’s sonnets and immerse yourself in the beauty of his verse before tackling some of his great characters.

Learn about structure and meter, understand the meaning and employ tools that help the language become part of you as you bring his words “to flesh.”
ShortDesc: Join professional artists from the Massachusetts-based Elements Theatre Company to unlock the secrets of Shakespeare’s sonnets and immerse yourself in the beauty of his verse before tackling some of his great characters.
Title: Shakespeare Residency Workshop with Elements Theatre Company

Description:
On the page this text is a bear. But, oh boy, does it work on the stage.

I love it and believe that you will too. I’ve directed this wonderful play twice. It's glorious language, biting satire and unashamed burlesque with an emotional sting at the end that should reach right down inside of you. Terrific!

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: On the page this text is a bear. But, oh boy, does it work on the stage.
Title: Love's Labour’s Lost

Description:
It’s the Trojan War. Seven years ago Troy’s Prince Paris snatched stunning Helen from her Greek husband. And the exhausting, spiteful conflagration drags on.

What a provocative setting for a love story, or maybe more properly stated, a lust story. Riverside Shakespeare says, “The modern theater has decided firmly, and rightly, that the play’s a brilliant scarifying vision of the world torn to pieces … its intellectualism, savagery and disillusion speak forcefully to contemporary audiences.” I think you will love it.

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: It’s the Trojan War. Seven years ago Troy’s Prince Paris snatched stunning Helen from her Greek husband. And the exhausting, spiteful conflagration drags on.
Title: Troilus & Cressida

Description:
The older I wax the more I understand and admire this brilliant and emotionally complex masterwork.

It’s Shakespeare’s final tragedy and maybe his most 21st century thinking. Military prowess, fame and politics are exposed in this astonishingly graphic glare at private faces in public places. My favorite Shakespeare play. Wow!

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: The older I wax the more I understand and admire this brilliant and emotionally complex masterwork.
Title: Coriolanus

Description:
“While in Rome...”

For our third play at “Friday Shakespeare,” we’ll tackle the wildly popular Julius Caesar. Private faces in public places! “Friends, Romans, Countrymen...” Here’s a play that many first encountered in high school. But, as with Coriolanus there’s a depth of examination of human character that rewards adult observation. Friendship, trust, ennobled objectives and human foibles are woven into the tapestry of this beloved tale of huge ego and ultimate destruction.

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: “While in Rome...” For our third play at “Friday Shakespeare,” we’ll tackle the wildly popular Julius Caesar.
Title: Julius Caesar with Bob Smith

Description:
Hamlet’s the high water mark in Western literature.

For those also taking Troilus and Cressida on Wednesdays at noon, here’s what could be a superb juxtaposition! The play digs deep into fathers and mothers and sons and daughters. This time we’ll look through the prism of Hamlet’s disenchantment with his mother and his heart-breaking disentanglement from poor Ophelia. There isn’t a better play!  For those in both sessions, look for a dialogue between this well known classic and the awesome bitterness of the lesser known play, Troilus and Cressida.

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: Hamlet’s the high water mark in Western literature.
Title: Hamlet with Bob Smith

Description:
“All the world’s a stage...” No play could more perfectly launch this brand new Friday Shakespeare series with Bob Smith!

This well-loved masterwork is a manual for love and courtship, and no instructor could be more qualified than Shakespeare’s glorious Rosalind. Touchstone’s fooling, Orlando’s purity, vain Phoebe, worshipful Sylvius, sexy goat herd Audrey, and the world-weary Jaques people this phenomenally good-natured play. Is it an accident that Shakespeare set his romantic classroom in the bucolic forest of Arden [his mother’s maiden name]? “...Come, woo me, woo me; now I am in a holiday humor... ”

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: “All the world’s a stage...” No play could more perfectly launch this brand new Friday Shakespeare series with Bob Smith!
Title: As You Like It with Bob Smith

Description:
“I long to embrace, to include in my own short life, all that is accessible to man. I long to speak, to read, to wield a hammer in a great factory, to keep watch at sea, to plow. I want to be walking […] in the open fields, or on the ocean—wherever my imagination ranges,” writes Anton Chekhov.

Chekhov is considered to be one of the world’s most popular playwrights. His tales—astute, economical and often humorous—are equally remarkable and influential. Join Liza Knapp, who returns to 92Y by popular demand, and read Chekhov’s tales with an eye to understanding how they explore the human condition.

 

Brief Bio

Liza Knapp teaches and writes about the Russian classics, both within the Russian context and in relation to their counterparts in English, French and American literature. She has served as the online “literary expert” for Oprah Winfrey’s Book Club and chairs the Slavic department at Columbia University.

A student writes: “Liza Knapp is hands down and far and away the best professor I encountered. Very knowledgeable, extremely patient and incredibly insightful. Even if you have read the material before, you will get a thousand times more out of it with her as your guide. Most importantly, she is truly excited about what she is teaching, and you can tell that she loves it.”
ShortDesc: “I long to embrace, to include in my own short life, all that is accessible to man. I long to speak, to read, to wield a hammer in a great factory, to keep watch at sea, to plow. I want to be walking … in the open fields, or on the ocean—wherever my imagination ranges,” writes Anton Chekhov.
Title: Readings Chekhov’s Tales with Liza Knapp

Description:
The beauty of slow reading applies to drama as well as the novel.

In the spirit of recent revivals, this summer we will be examining deep themes within this four-act play.

Please bring a copy of Three Sisters by Chekhov.
ShortDesc: The beauty of slow reading applies to drama as well as the novel.
Title: Slow Reading: Three Sisters by Chekhov

Description:
From 1956 to 2002, Saul Bellow made regular appearances at 92Y. To celebrate his centenary, friends and fellow writers gather to read from his work. “The backbone of 20th-century American literature has been provided by two novelists—William Faulkner and Saul Bellow,” wrote Philip Roth. “Together they are the Melville, Hawthorne and Twain of the 20th century.”

 

This reading is endowed in memory of Ronald Busch.
ShortDesc: To celebrate Saul Bellow’s centenary, friends and fellow writers gather to read from his work.
Title: Saul Bellow at 100

Description: Acclaimed pianist Jeremy Denk interviews British tenor Ian Bostridge, whose performances of Winterreise “haunt the imagination long after the notes have died away” (New York Magazine) and whose new book, Schubert’s Winterreise: Anatomy of an Obsession, offers a personal examination of the song cycle’s literary, historical and psychological themes. "He is not only a lyric tenor of uncanny focus and intensity but also an accredited scholar and deft commentator on musical matters,” wrote Alex Ross.
MobileDesc: Acclaimed pianist Jeremy Denk interviews British tenor Ian Bostridge, whose performances of Winterreise “haunt the imagination long after the notes have died away” (New York Magazine) and whose new book, Schubert’s Winterreise: Anatomy of an Obsession, offers a personal examination of the song cycle’s literary, historical and psychological themes. "He is not only a lyric tenor of uncanny focus and intensity but also an accredited scholar and deft commentator on musical matters,” wrote Alex Ross.
ShortDesc: Acclaimed pianist Jeremy Denk interviews British tenor Ian Bostridge, whose new book offers a personal examination of the song cycle’s literary, historical and psychological themes.
Title: Winterreise: Anatomy of an Obsession with Ian Bostridge and Jeremy Denk

Description: Best known as a playwright (Art, Life x 3, God of Carnage), French author Yasmina Reza makes her Poetry Center debut with the publication of her new novel, Happy are the Happy—“a spiky, brilliantly observed novel about marriage, infidelity, dreams and disillusion,” wrote The Telegraph.
ShortDesc: Best known as a playwright (Art, Life x 3, God of Carnage), French author Yasmina Reza makes her Poetry Center debut with the publication of her new novel, Happy are the Happy—“a spiky, brilliantly observed novel about marriage, infidelity, dreams and disillusion,” wrote The Telegraph.
Title: Yasmina Reza

Description:
In his new collection of stories, Let Me Be Frank with You, Richard Ford reinvents his beloved character, Frank Bascombe, in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. He has “forged a new way of writing fiction about, and out of, American life that is as revolutionary as Proust’s adventures in time travel,” wrote John Banville. Lorrie Moore’s recent collection of stories is Bark. Her work “still dazzles,” wrote Bonnie Jo Campbell. “For all their genuine sadness and existential angst, these powerfully, almost savagely, human stories shine with a spirit of playfulness and the logic of love.”

 

Presented in association with the Irish Arts Center.
ShortDesc: In his new collection of stories, Let Me Be Frank with You, Richard Ford reinvents his beloved character, Frank Bascombe, in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. Lorrie Moore’s recent collection of stories is Bark.
Title: Richard Ford and Lorrie Moore

Description:
A dramatic reading from the letters of Langston Hughes, now published in a comprehensive edition for the first time and offering readers the full picture of a generous, visionary and gratifyingly good man who was a genius of modern American literature.

Edited by Arnold Rampersad and David Roessel, this volume of correspondence—with Carl Van Vechten, Blanche Knopf, Zora Neale Hurston, Arna Bontemps, Countee Cullen, Ezra Pound, Paul Robeson and James Baldwin—shows Hughes as a young writer finding his voice; struggling to support himself in a hostile landscape; using his artistic clout in the service of the disenfranchised; and bravely laughing at the world.
MobileDesc: A dramatic reading from the letters of Langston Hughes, now published in a comprehensive edition for the first time and offering readers the full picture of a generous, visionary and gratifyingly good man who was a genius of modern American literature. Edited by Arnold Rampersad and David Roessel, this volume of correspondence—with Carl Van Vechten, Blanche Knopf, Zora Neale Hurston, Arna Bontemps, Countee Cullen, Ezra Pound, Paul Robeson and James Baldwin—shows Hughes as a young writer finding his voice; struggling to support himself in a hostile landscape; using his artistic clout in the service of the disenfranchised; and bravely laughing at the world.
ShortDesc: A dramatic reading from the letters of Langston Hughes, now published in a comprehensive edition for the first time and offering readers the full picture of a generous, visionary and gratifyingly good man who was a genius of modern American literature.
Title: The Letters of Langston Hughes

Description:
A place that ever was lived in is like a fire that never goes out.

In advance of the inaugural Eudora Welty Biennial, which opens in April 2015 down in Jackson with a theme of Classical Mississippi, the Poetry Center presents a reading of Asphodel, a story of three women visiting a country estate in memory of an eccentric friend who recently passed away. To travel with Eudora Welty “was to have the world narrated to you, recalibrated and transformed into language that was surprising, sometimes shocking, always sympathetic, frequently hilarious and full of perception, wonder and delight,” wrote Richard Ford.
ShortDesc: In advance of the inaugural Eudora Welty Biennial, the Poetry Center presents a reading of Asphodel, a story of three women visiting a country estate in memory of an eccentric friend who recently passed away.
Title: Eudora Welty’s Asphodel

Description:
Upon publication of his new book, Curiosity, Alberto Manguel—renowned for his learned yet felicitous investigations of how writers and readers meet and change each other—takes on a special assignment: to read a work he’s never read before, then discuss the experience of this literary encounter.

“His imagination is supple and generous, and his work is full of surprises,” wrote A. S. Byatt. “His reflections, so unconstricted, so clear, so strange, are so very satisfying to his readers.”
ShortDesc: Upon publication of his new book, Curiosity, Alberto Manguel—renowned for his learned yet felicitous investigations of how writers and readers meet and change each other—takes on a special assignment: to read a work he’s never read before, then discuss the experience of this literary encounter.
Title: Alberto Manguel: First Reads

Description: Kazuo Ishiguro’s new novel—about lost memories, love, revenge and war—is The Buried Giant. “He is one of the finest prose stylists of our time,” wrote Michael Ondaatje. Caryl Phillips’ new novel, a story of orphans and outcasts inspired by Wuthering Heights, is The Lost Child. “Ever since the first of his books, Phillips has been trying, with unusual seriousness and concentration, to rewrite English literature by filling in the gaps, the black holes, in the country’s official story of itself,” wrote Pico Iyer. “Yet where others complain about history, he sets about remaking it, in more inclusive terms.”
ShortDesc: Kazuo Ishiguro’s new novel—about lost memories, love, revenge and war—is The Buried Giant. Caryl Phillips’ new novel, a story of orphans and outcasts inspired by Wuthering Heights, is The Lost Child.
Title: Kazuo Ishiguro and Caryl Phillips

Description:
A rare New York appearance by poet Jay Wright.

When he was awarded the prestigious Bollingen Prize for Lifetime Achievement, the judges (Elizabeth Alexander, James Longenbach and Carl Phillips) praised his work for “daring to extend the tradition of the prophetic voice. For more than 40 years it has been nothing less than a sustained meditation on the various aspects—historical, spiritual, mythical—of which humanity is woven.”
ShortDesc: A rare New York appearance by poet Jay Wright.
Title: Jay Wright

Description: Mary Caponegro’s recent collection of stories is All Fall Down. “She is one of our great national literary treasures,” wrote George Saunders. “A daring writer who reminds us in every line that the true business of fiction is intelligence and presence and compassion." Steven Millhauser’s new collection of stories is Voices in the Night. “He is a quiet, enigmatic master,” wrote Jonathan Lethem. “His prose draws equally on Nabokovian rapture, Borgesian enigma and the plain-spoken white-picket-fence wistfulness of Sherwood Anderson.”
ShortDesc: Mary Caponegro’s recent collection of stories is All Fall Down. Steven Millhauser’s new collection of stories is Voices in the Night.
Title: Mary Caponegro and Steven Millhauser

Description:
Awarded the National Medal of Arts in 2012, Rita Dove was praised by President Obama for “creating works that are equal parts beauty, lyricism, critique, and politics . . . and advocating on behalf of the diversity and vitality of American poetry and literature.”

This National Poetry Month, Dove continues a long-standing Poetry Center tradition by curating and introducing readings by three of her favorite poets: Alex Dimitrov, TJ Jarrett and Safiya Sinclair.
ShortDesc: Awarded the National Medal of Arts in 2012, Rita Dove was praised by President Obama for “creating works that are equal parts beauty, lyricism, critique, and politics . . . and advocating on behalf of the diversity and vitality of American poetry and literature.”
Title: The Tenth Muse with Rita Dove

Description:
The Joan Leiman Jacobson Poetry Prizes are presented by the 92Y Unterberg Poetry Center and Boston Review.

The “Discovery” Poetry Contest is designed to attract large audiences to poets who have not yet published a full-length book. Four winners are awarded a reading at 92Y, publication in Boston Review and $500 each. Many winners of this contest have gone on to distinguished careers as poets, among them Lucille Clifton, Nick Flynn, David St. John and Mark Strand.

The preliminary judges for the 2015 contest are Timothy Donnelly and Camille Rankine. The final judges are Peter Gizzi, Atsuro Riley and Susan Stewart. The deadline for receipt of manuscripts is 5 pm on Fri, Jan 23, 2015. For complete contest guidelines, and to apply, visit 92Y.org/Discovery.

This contest is endowed by Joan L. and Dr. Julius H. Jacobson, II.

 

Post-reading reception is sponsored by Brooklyn Brewery.
MobileDesc: The Joan Leiman Jacobson Poetry Prizes are presented by the 92Y Unterberg Poetry Center and Boston Review.
ShortDesc: The Joan Leiman Jacobson Poetry Prizes are presented by the 92Y Unterberg Poetry Center and Boston Review.
Title: Discovery/Boston Review Poetry Contest Winners' Reading

Description: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, who won Best New Plays at this year’s OBIE Awards for Appropriate and An Octoroon, has two new plays premiering in the coming months: War at Yale Repertory and Gloria; or Ambition at the Vineyard Theatre. His plays are as “funny as they are unsettling, rejecting political orthodoxies and messing around with ontology,” wrote the Village Voice. Paula Vogel’s most recent play is Don Juan Comes Home from Iraq. Her plays “go for the throat with enormous humanity, humor and intelligence,” wrote Anne Bogart.
ShortDesc: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, who won Best New Plays at this year’s OBIE Awards for Appropriate and An Octoroon, has two new plays premiering in the coming months: War at Yale Repertory and Gloria; or Ambition at the Vineyard Theatre. Paula Vogel’s most recent play is Don Juan Comes Home from Iraq.
Title: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and Paula Vogel

Description:
In more than 50 books, Robert Kelly has given readers “dream narratives, elegies, prayers, anecdotes, parables, dialogues, and folktales from a land that may not exist,” wrote Bookforum. “He has done something remarkable. He has given magic back its dignity, finding it in human warmth.” Sinéad Morrissey won the T. S. Eliot Prize for her latest collection, Parallax, which comes out in the U.S. this spring. “She is one of a number of younger poets from Northern Ireland who are negotiating the mixed blessing of having such illustrious antecedents as Mahon and Heaney,” wrote The Guardian. “To honor such an inheritance requires all the confidence and care of a high-wire act. With its incisive imagery and taut rhythms, her poetry comes to us with the intimacy of whispered secrets.”

 

Presented in association with the Irish Arts Center.
ShortDesc: In more than 50 books, Robert Kelly has given readers “dream narratives, elegies, prayers, anecdotes, parables, dialogues, and folktales from a land that may not exist,” wrote Bookforum. Sinéad Morrissey won the T. S. Eliot Prize for her latest collection, Parallax.
Title: Robert Kelly and Sinéad Morrissey

Description:
From 1956 to 2002, Saul Bellow made regular appearances at 92Y. To celebrate his centenary, friends and fellow writers gather to read from his work. “The backbone of 20th-century American literature has been provided by two novelists—William Faulkner and Saul Bellow,” wrote Philip Roth. “Together they are the Melville, Hawthorne and Twain of the 20th century.”

 

This reading is endowed in memory of Ronald Busch.
ShortDesc: To celebrate Saul Bellow’s centenary, friends and fellow writers gather to read from his work.
Title: Saul Bellow at 100

Description:
Exploring the key role that music plays in the novels of Ian McEwan, the writer, pianist and baritone present an evening of reading, conversation and performance.

“He has four recordings here and selects not the showy unorthodoxies of Glenn Gould, but Angela Hewitt’s wise and silky playing,” writes McEwan in his novel Saturday. Since praising her fictionally in 2005, the real-life writer has struck up a collaborative friendship with the pianist. Joined by baritone Russell Braun, they now bring their words-and-music partnership to 92Y.
MobileDesc: Exploring the key role that music plays in the novels of Ian McEwan, the writer, pianist and baritone present an evening of reading, conversation and performance. “He has four recordings here and selects not the showy unorthodoxies of Glenn Gould, but Angela Hewitt’s wise and silky playing,” writes McEwan in his novel Saturday. Since praising her fictionally in 2005, the real-life writer has struck up a collaborative friendship with the pianist. Joined by baritone Russell Braun, they now bring their words-and-music partnership to 92Y.
ShortDesc: Exploring the key role that music plays in the novels of Ian McEwan, the writer, pianist and baritone present an evening of reading, conversation and performance.
Title: The Music of McEwan with Ian McEwan, Angela Hewitt and Russell Braun

Description:
Dame Hilary Mantel is the two-time winner of the Man Booker Prize for her best-selling novels, Wolf Hall, and its sequel, Bring Up the Bodies—an unprecedented achievement.

The Royal Shakespeare Company recently adapted Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies for the stage to colossal critical acclaim, which opens on Broadway in April. There is also a BBC/Masterpiece six-part adaption of the novels, which will be broadcast on PBS in 2015.

The author of fourteen books, Mantel is currently at work on the third installment of the Thomas Cromwell Trilogy, The Mirror & the Light.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.
MobileDesc:

There is also a BBC/Masterpiece six-part adaption of the novels, which will be broadcast on PBS in 2015.

The author of fourteen books, Mantel is currently at work on the third installment of the Thomas Cromwell Trilogy, The Mirror & the Light.

Title: From Book to Broadway: A Conversation with Wolf Hall's Hilary Mantel

Description: An exclusive New York appearance by Nobel Laureate Toni Morrison, who will read from and discuss her new novel, God Help the Child, a searing tale about the way childhood trauma shapes and misshapes the life of the adult. Morrison is “the most important writer writing in English today,” said Junot Díaz.
MobileDesc: An exclusive New York appearance by Nobel Laureate Toni Morrison, who will read from and discuss her new novel, God Help the Child, a searing tale about the way childhood trauma shapes and misshapes the life of the adult. Morrison is “the most important writer writing in English today,” said Junot Díaz.
ShortDesc: An exclusive New York appearance by Nobel Laureate Toni Morrison, who will read from and discuss her new novel, God Help the Child, a searing tale about the way childhood trauma shapes and misshapes the life of the adult.
Title: Toni Morrison

Description:
Celebrated Israeli writer Etgar Keret is known best for his spare, absurd stories that display his remarkable talent as a miniaturist.

Join Keret as he speaks to James Snyder, director of the Israel Museum, about the paradoxes of modern life and his knack for transforming those moments into unforgettable stories that have merited him comparison to Kafka, Vonnegut and Woody Allen.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.
MobileDesc: Celebrated Israeli writer Etgar Keret is known best for his spare, absurd stories that display his remarkable talent as a miniaturist. Join Keret as he speaks to James Snyder, director of the Israel Museum, about the paradoxes of modern life and his knack for transforming those moments into unforgettable stories that have merited him comparison to Kafka, Vonnegut and Woody Allen.
ShortDesc: Celebrated Israeli writer Etgar Keret is known best for his spare, absurd stories that display his remarkable talent as a miniaturist.
Title: The Surreal World of Etgar Keret: Etgar Keret in Conversation with James Snyder

Description:
In the Unlikely Event is the new adult novel from the beloved and bestselling author Judy Blume.

When a series of passenger airplanes crashed in Elizabeth, New Jersey within a three-month period in 1951–1952, Judy Blume was a teenager. “These events have lingered in my mind ever since,” says Blume. “It was a crazy time. We were witnessing things that were incomprehensible to us as teenagers. Was it sabotage? An alien invasion? No one knew, and people were understandably terrified.” Against this background, Blume uses her imagination to bring us the lives of three generations of families, friends and strangers, who will be profoundly affected by these events, either directly or indirectly. But life goes on and Blume digs deep into her characters—we see them coping not only with grief but with first love, estranged parents, difficult friendships, familial obligations, divorce, career ambitions, a grandparent’s love, a widower’s hope and everything in between . . . Most important, In the Unlikely Event is filled with the same warmth and authenticity that have won Blume the hearts and minds of readers of all generations.

 

Brief Bio

Judy Blume is one of America’s most beloved authors. Her twenty-eight titles include Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret; Forever; and Summer Sisters. Together, her books have sold more than 85 million copies in 32 languages. She is a champion of intellectual freedom, working with the National Coalition Against Censorship to support teachers, librarians and students who fight to keep challenged books on their shelves. In 2004, Blume was awarded the National Book Foundation’s Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters. She lives in Key West, Forida, with her husband.

When a series of passenger airplanes crashed in Elizabeth, New Jersey within a three-month period in 1951–1952, Judy Blume was a teenager. “These events have lingered in my mind ever since,” says Blume. “It was a crazy time. We were witnessing things that were incomprehensible to us as teenagers. Was it sabotage? An alien invasion? No one knew, and people were understandably terrified.” Against this background, Blume uses her imagination to bring us the lives of three generations of families, friends and strangers, who will be profoundly affected by these events, either directly or indirectly. But life goes on and Blume digs deep into her characters—we see them coping not only with grief but with first love, estranged parents, difficult friendships, familial obligations, divorce, career ambitions, a grandparent’s love, a widower’s hope and everything in between . . . Most important, In the Unlikely Event is filled with the same warmth and authenticity that have won Blume the hearts and minds of readers of all generations.
ShortDesc: In the Unlikely Event is the new adult novel from the beloved and bestselling author Judy Blume.
Title: An Evening with Judy Blume

Description:
A much-anticipated appearance by the international literary star whose My Struggle series “has broken the sound barrier of the autobiographical novel,” wrote Jeffrey Eugenides. “Reading him, you feel you’re absorbing the complete portrait of an entire life.”

In My Struggle: Book Four, which will be published in April, the eighteen-year-old Karl Ove takes a job as a teacher in a remote fishing village. Looking back at his high-school years, his parents’ separation and his first love, he begins his life as an artist.
MobileDesc: A much-anticipated appearance by the international literary star whose My Struggle series “has broken the sound barrier of the autobiographical novel,” wrote Jeffrey Eugenides. “Reading him, you feel you’re absorbing the complete portrait of an entire life.” In My Struggle: Book Four, which will be published in April, the eighteen-year-old Karl Ove takes a job as a teacher in a remote fishing village. Looking back at his high-school years, his parents’ separation and his first love, he begins his life as an artist.

Title: Karl Ove Knausgaard

Description: Children's Reading Series
ShortDesc: Saturday-afternoon programs for story-loving kids of all ages, featuring lively readings by authors and actors!
Title: Children's Reading Series

Description:
For Leon Fleisher, Schubert’s B-flat major sonata is an “ultimate piece.”

He sits down with his son Julian Fleisher to discuss Schubert’s special place in his world. This is the third in a series of three conversations between Leon and Julian Fleisher, exploring the master’s life and career through the lens of the music he loves.
MobileDesc: For Leon Fleisher, Schubert’s B-flat major sonata is an “ultimate piece.” He sits down with his son Julian Fleisher to discuss Schubert’s special place in his world. This is the third in a series of three conversations between Leon and Julian Fleisher, exploring the master’s life and career through the lens of the music he loves.
ShortDesc: For Leon Fleisher, Schubert’s B-flat major sonata is an “ultimate piece.”
Title: Leon Fleisher: Living Through Music—On Seeing Through Schubert

Description:
Drawing on newly published letters and diaries, Edward Mendelson offers a provocative reassessment of the lives and work of eight influential 20th-century American writers: Lionel Trilling, Dwight Macdonald, W. H. Auden, William Maxwell, Saul Bellow, Alfred Kazin, Norman Mailer and Frank O’Hara.

“Mendelson’s observations about literature are among the best I have read: deeply knowledgeable, appreciative and attentive,” wrote Shirley Hazzard.
ShortDesc: Drawing on newly published letters and diaries, Edward Mendelson offers a provocative reassessment of the lives and work of eight influential 20th-century American writers.
Title: Moral Agents:  Eight Twentieth-Century Writers with Edward Mendelson

Description:
Upon publication of a new biography of the poet by Langdon Hammer, his friends gather to discuss his life and work.

Merrill was “Mozartian in the range of his art—from the lightest to the most somber and funereal, from the intricacies of sonnets to symphonic grandeurs,” wrote Anthony Hecht. “In this regard, he has no real match among twentieth-century poets writing in English.”
ShortDesc: Upon publication of a new biography of the poet by Langdon Hammer, his friends gather to discuss his life and work.
Title: On James Merrill

Description:
“Elizabeth Bishop began with the idea that little is known and that much is puzzling,” Colm Tóibín has written. “The effort then to make a true statement in poetry required a hushed, solitary concentration.” Tóibín explores her “poetics of uncertainty” in his new critical appreciation, On Elizabeth Bishop.

 

Presented in association with the Irish Arts Center.
ShortDesc: “Elizabeth Bishop began with the idea that little is known and that much is puzzling,” Colm Tóibín has written.
Title: On Elizabeth Bishop with Colm Tóibín
